questions.question_text: Which command is the correct way to summarize routes that were injected into OSPF area 100 from RIP?

discussion.content:
Correct is B

Summarization on ASBRs
Summarization can also be performed for external routes, as illustrated in Figure 3-27. Each route that is redistributed into OSPF from other protocols is advertised individually with an external LSA. To reduce the size of the OSPF LSDB, you can configure a summary for external routes. Summarization of external routes can be done on the ASBR for type 5 LSAs (redistributed routes) before injecting them into the OSPF domain. Without summarization, all the redistributed external prefixes from external autonomous systems are passed into the OSPF area. A summary route to Null0 is created automatically for each summary range.

The ASBR will summarize external routes before injecting them into the OSPF domain as type 5 external LSAs. Table 3-4 shows the parameters used with the summary-address command. To remove a the summarization, use the no form of this command

http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2294214&seqNum=3
We are talking about redistributed routes. So we'are talking about redistribution that is made in ASBR..so the right command is summary-address

comments.content:
D is not correct. "ip summery-address" is used when summerizing internal EIGRP routes. The "summery-address" command summerizes external routes being redist'ed into OSPF. Pay attention to the "ip" at the beginning of the command.

The correct answer is B

discussion.content:
B

“The summary-address subcommand defines the summary route on the ASBR, with similar syntax and parameters as compared to the area range command seen on ABRs.”

Excerpt From: Kevin Wallace. “CCNP Routing and Switching ROUTE 300-101 Official Cert Guide.” iBooks.

questions.question_text: The OSPF database of a router shows LSA types 1, 2, 7, and 3 default router only. Which type of area is this router connected to?

comments.content: The correct answer is A (Although it's phrased improperly, it's technically a "Totally NSSA")

discussion.content: I thought this should be D

questions.question_text: A network engineer is investigating the cause of a service disruption on a network segment and executes the debug condition interface fastethernet f0/0 command. In which situation is the debugging output generated?

discussion.content:
D is wrong - cant receive packet on a shutdown interface!
A,B,C - can receive packets debug will work! lol

@abuyia:
imo, since the debug is placed on the interface, the int must be up (operational) for logs to be generated. right?
can someone explain to me what it meant by that answer

choices.C: when packets on the interface are received and forwarded to a configured syslog server
choices.B: when packets on the interface are received and logging buffered is enabled
choices.D: when packets on the interface are received and the interface is shut down
choices.A: when packets on the interface are received and the interface is operational

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. When summarizing these routes, which route is the summarized route?
//IMG//
Which type of BGP AS number is 64591?

discussion.content: Sorry it was my bad, the question is correct, please remove my comment, thank you!

ASN 64591 is not within 16bit private range (64512 - 65534) nor within 32bit private range (4200000000 - 4294967294). It's not even a 32bit public ASN. In fact it's within 32bit reserved range (65552 - 131071). So either the question is wrong or it's a typo.
